entry.title: Re: Preventing Negative Balances in Cost Centers in SAP P...
entry.content:
Thanks Alvaro for your question and thanks Chris for the excellent answer.

There is a reason for not providing checks to prevent negative balances on cost centers.
Depending on the cost allocation method you use, negative balances can occur and are not by default something you want to prevent.

  • If universal allocation is used to move costs from cost centers to other receivers, you normally define a rule that moves 100% of the costs to other receivers, this method ensures a balance of zero on the sending cost center at period end.
  • With activity allocation cost centers normally have a balance at period end, if. e.g. cost postings are still missing or the cost rates are too high, this balance could also run below zero.
    In this case a balance check could for example prevent time confirmations and this is very often something you do not want to have.
    Therefore it is sometimes better to not directly block postings but ensure that someone gets informed if the balance runs below zero. Because as said, this does not always mean that something is wrong.

Again thanks for connecting and discussing via the SAP Community.

Best regards, Birgit

entry.title: Standardize Resource Creation with Reusable Resource Types in SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Tired of re-entering the same details for every contractor or piece of equipment? Resource types help you prefill and control data so you can create resources faster and with fewer errors.

If youâ€™re spending time manually keying addresses, job codes, or work schedules for every new resourceâ€”and still ending up with inconsistent recordsâ€”youâ€™re not alone. That repetition slows onboarding, complicates audits, and makes creating resource records harder than it needs to be.

What You Can Do with SAP Fieldglass

  • Build once, reuse everywhere: With resource types, you define the basicsâ€”labor or equipment, address, job code, time tracking, work schedule, activity checklist, and moreâ€”once. Then you use that resource type as a template any time you create a resource.
  • Reduce data entry and improve quality: Admins can lock, hide, or default specific fields in the resource type. That means fewer fields to touch, fewer errors to chase, and standardized data across business units and suppliers. When you create a resource from a type, key fields and any custom fields carry over automatically.
  • Engage both labor and equipment: Resource types support people and assets. Labor resources can register and log in to SAP Fieldglass to manage and complete assigned work items (for example, SOW line items).
  • Keep governance and visibility: The system audit trail records create, edit, and remove activities for resource types. Reporting is straightforward, with data points such as Resource ID, Equipment ID, Equipment Name, and Type available. If you use integrations, the Resource Upload and Resource Download connectors support this capability for bulk operations.

How it works (at a glance):

  1. Create a resource type from Admin > Worker > Resource Type, and set defaults (labor or equipment, job code, time tracking, work schedule, and any required checklists or custom fields).
  2. Create a resource by selecting that type; the predefined fields are applied automatically.
  3. Activate the resource. Labor resources receive an email invitation to register and then move to Open; equipment resources move directly to Open on activation.

 Caveats & Tips

  • Permissions first. Make sure the right user role permissions are enabled for the Resource Type module before you start.
  • Pick the right type up front. Resource records inherit whether the type is Labor or Equipment; that choice determines the lifecycle and what the resource can do.
  • Plan activation. If you donâ€™t enable auto activation, new resources start in Pending Activation. Labor resources receive an invitation email to create an SAP Fieldglass account upon activation, and then move to Open. Equipment resources move directly to Open on activation.
  • Govern with custom fields. Use custom fieldsâ€”and the ability to lock, hide, or default valuesâ€”to enforce naming conventions, cost centers, locations, or other critical attributes. You can create custom fields specific to labor or equipment.

What to Do Next

  • Set up reusable templates for labor or equipment: Creating a Resource Type (SAP Help Portal).
  • Quickly create resources from your templates: Creating a Resource (SAP Help Portal).

entry.title: Fetching ErrorInformation from CPI Message Processing Logs
entry.content:
The Challenge

The CPI environment uses External Logging to send logs to Splunk. There, the LastError field is readily available:

Important: The LastError field is also populated for messages with status COMPLETED - when an error was caught and handled properly in the iFlow. This is valuable for monitoring because you can see errors that were gracefully handled and potentially returned to the sender system, even though the message processing itself succeeded.

However, when querying the OData v2 API (/api/v1/MessageProcessingLogs), this field is not exposed. The ErrorInformation is only available as a deferred navigation property:

{
  "ErrorInformation": {
    "__deferred": {
      "uri": ".../MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations('guid')"
    }
  }
}

What I Tested

$expand=ErrorInformation

GET /MessageProcessingLogs?$expand=ErrorInformation

Result: 501 Not Implemented

This is the most obvious approach, but CPI doesn't support it. There are SAP Influence requests for this:

  • #296909
  • #309960

$select=LastError

GET /MessageProcessingLogs('guid')?$select=MessageGuid,LastError,Status

Result: Field not available in API response

The LastError field exists internally (Splunk receives it), but is not exposed via OData.

OData $batch Request

POST /$batch
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=batch_123

Result: 404 - The $batch endpoint doesn't exist for MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations

What Works

The only method I found is calling each message individually:

GET /MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations('MessageGuid')/$value

This returns the plain text error message. But for thousands of messages, this means thousands of API calls.

Open Question

I'm currently using parallel HTTP requests as a workaround, but it feels inefficient when Splunk already receives this data automatically via External Logging.

Has anyone found a better approach? Maybe there's an undocumented feature or a way to access the External Logging stream directly?

Let me know in the comments!

entry.title: MCP vs. API: The Evolution of AI Interaction (Easy Explanation)
entry.content:
MCP vs. API: The Evolution of AI Interaction

Ever wonder how an AI assistant might one day not just tell you how to book a flight, but actually go ahead and book it for you, dealing with all the different websites and steps? That leap from just giving information to truly taking action is being driven by a fascinating new development called Model Context Protocol (MCP), and it's changing how AI interacts with the digital world.

To understand MCP, let's first look at what we've been using:

  • APIs (Application Programming Interfaces): The "Instruction Manuals" Think of an API as a very precise instruction manual for software. If you want a computer program to talk to another program (like your banking app talking to your bank's server), an API provides the exact, step-by-step commands and data formats they need to use.

  • It's like telling a chef, "Take exactly two cups of flour, add one egg, and mix for 30 seconds."

  • APIs are rigid and require you (or a human programmer) to know every single instruction to get a specific result.

  • MCP (Model Context Protocol): The "Smart Assistant" Now, imagine if instead of a detailed manual, you had a super-smart assistant. You could simply say, "I'm hungry, find me something healthy and delicious."

  • This assistant wouldn't need you to tell it exactly which dish from which restaurant. It would understand your goal, look at all the available options (menus!), assess them based on your preferences, and then intelligently decide what to order and how to get it done. MCP gives AI agents this kind of intelligent autonomy.

The Key Difference: With APIs, you tell the system how to do something. With MCP, you tell the AI agent what you want to achieve, and it figures out the how.

Why is this a big deal for AI?

MCP allows AI systems to:

  • Discover and use tools on their own: They don't need to be pre-programmed for every specific action.
  • Chain actions together: They can perform multi-step tasks seamlessly, like finding a contact, drafting an email, and sending it, all without manual intervention.
  • Adapt on the fly: As new tools become available or existing one's change, the AI agent can quickly understand and integrate them into its capabilities.

Will MCP replace APIs?

Not at all! They work together!

APIs are the essential building blocks â€“ the digital "plumbing." MCP is the intelligent layer that sits on top, allowing AI agents to smartly use and orchestrate those existing API connections. MCP makes existing APIs "AI-ready."

This shift means AI is becoming less about following instructions and more about understanding what you want and autonomously figuring out the best way to get it done. It's an exciting step towards truly capable AI agents.

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating Functional Locations and Equipment master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Risk Management, Incident Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining asset-related data manually within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on validated Plant Maintenance (PM) master data coming from the customerâ€™s existing ERP landscape. This ensures that all structures, machines, and technical objects involved in EHS processes remain consistent, reliable, and audit-proof across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date Functional Location and Equipment data is essential because many EHS processes depend on a clear understanding of where work is performed and which technical objects is affected. This includes:

  • Identifying the exact machine or installation involved in an incident
  • Linking hazards to the correct technical asset in Risk Assessments
  • Performing control inspections and assigning follow-up actions
  • Ensuring asset-specific exposure, material usage, or emission characteristics are correctly evaluated
  • Centralizing reporting across operational sites based on real asset hierarchies

In other words: Without integrated Functional Location and Equipment data, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot reliably assess risks, evaluate hazards, track incidents, or produce compliant operational reports.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post â€“ focusing on the integration of Functional Locations and Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Reference to User Scenario (B) â€“ Risk Management

In part 1 â€œIntroduction & Overviewâ€, the User Scenario (B) â€“ Risk Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Plant Maintenance (PM) Integration Matters

A supervisor identifies a hazard in the chemical handling area

The hazard must be assigned to the correct Functional Location to ensure accurate traceability and reporting.

An Industrial Hygienist conducts a risk assessment

Equipment properties (e.g. ventilation units, storage cabinets, extraction systems) must be available from SAP PM to evaluate exposure and technical conditions.

Mitigation actions are defined

Some mitigation measures depend on technical object (e.g., upgrading ventilation, replacing equipment, updating signage).

A control inspection is performed

The inspection must reference the exact equipment or Functional Location where the mitigation is implemented.

Residual risk is recalculated

The correct asset hierarchy ensures that results are assigned to the right operational area or machine.

Results are shared with operations teams

Consistent Functional Location data ensures findings reach the correct plant, work center, or technical area.

Without integrated Functional Locations and Equipment, the system would not be able to:

  • Assign hazards or incidents to the correct asset
  • Trace risk assessments and inspections to the real technical environment
  • Evaluate machine-specific conditions and exposures
  • Monitor the effectiveness of mitigation actions at asset level
  • Ensure accurate reporting across operational areas and sites

Note: When implementing Risk Management as demonstrated in the user scenario, ensure that the relevant scope item 54A â€“ Health & Safety Management (for Risk Management) is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC). This activation enables the Risk Assessment and Control Inspection processes in SAP EHS Public Cloud so that synchronized Functional Locations and Equipment master data can be used consistently.

While this integration is mandatory for Risk Management, it is equally relevant for other EHS use cases such as Incident Management or Emissions Management. In all these processes, consistent asset data provides the foundation for identifying affected areas, assessing technical conditions, and enabling accurate regulatory reporting.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully integrate Plant Maintenance data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via the SAP Integration Suite, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

Tenant Provisioning:  

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant (with activated Plant Maintenance)
  • SAP Integration Suite tenant (Cloud Integration + Event Mesh)

Administrator Access: 

Ensure administrator users exist in all three systems: 

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: The administrator should have the template role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR assigned to allow the creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements. 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise: Users with access to the SPRO are required.
  • SAP Integration Suite: A User with admin rights for Event Mesh and iFlow deployment is required.

Scope Item Activation:  

Following scope items need to be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:

  • 4HH â€“ Reactive Maintenance (mandatory for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud communication scenario regarding the inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations).
  • 54A â€“ Health & Safety Management (required for Risk Management scenario).

Activated OData Services in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System:

  • API_EQUIPMENT and API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION active in SAP Gateway (check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE).

Event Mesh Instance:

  • Provisioned by SAP BTP with service key available (for AMQP connection).

These prerequisites ensure that the integration of Plant Maintenance â€“ specially changes made in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system â€“ operates smoothly and reliably, thereby supporting EHS processes such as Risk Management.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section provides an overview of the technical integration required to replicate Plant Maintenance master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for EHS processes.

The integration scenario builds on the activation of the scope item 4HH â€“ Reactive Maintenance, which delivers the necessary inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These objects form the foundation for EHS capabilities such as Risk Management, Incident Management, or Emissions Management.

The process shown in this integration scenario is event-driven. This means, whenever changes occur to Plant Maintenance master data, such as Equipment or Functional Location in the On-Premise system, these updates are automatically replicated to the Public Cloud. This approach keeps both systems aligned without manual steps or scheduled batch jobs, ensuring that asset information is always current.

Keeping master data synchronized between both systems is critical for effective Risk Management because risk assessments and mitigation strategies depend on accurate details about assets and their locations.

By ensuring that updates flow seamlessly between systems, organizations can make informed decisions and maintain compliance across their EHS processes.

Key Configuration Areas: 

  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration 
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration 
  • SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • Monitoring

3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration

As this integration scenario for Functional Locations and Equipment is event driven, the creation of channels was required in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to publish business events to the SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh.

In this context the channels define the protocol (AMQP), destination (Event Mesh service key), and topic space.

Outbound bindings specify which event topics (e.g., sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*) are sent. This ensures that changes in Functional Locations or Equipment trigger the corresponding iFlows in the SAP Integration Suite.

Channels can be created by navigating to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Administration > Chanel Connection Settings > Manage Channels and Parameters.

Therefore, we created the channel IS_INTERNAL_EVENTMESH which uses the AMQP Protocol.

Event Channels in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

After creating the channel, we added two outbound bindings to define which event topic should be published.

  • sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*
  • sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/*

Added Outbound Bindings to created Event Channel

This configuration ensures that business events for Functional Locations and Equipment are reliably published from the on-premise system to SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh, enabling event-driven iFlows without the need for polling.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. 

For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 â€“ Asset Management Master Data Integration is used.

By activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. 

To create the Communication Arrangement, we need to create a Communication User as well as a Communication System that will be assigned to the related Communication Arrangement.

3.2.1 Create Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g., user OPN_IN). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored in the Security Material of the SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems. 

Select Maintain Communication Users

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app â€œMaintain Communication Usersâ€.  

Select "New"

If no suitable user exists, select â€œNewâ€ to create one.

Created Communication User - General Data

The username and password for Basic Authentication can be freely defined. 

Related Communication System and Arrangements

Once created, the system automatically structures the user view, showing assignments to Communication Systems and Arrangements (added in later steps). 

3.2.2 Create Communication System

The Communication System is a necessary component for the Communication Arrangement. If you have already set up a Communication System for the S/4HANA On-Premise system, you can use it for the Communication Arrangement. Please note that the previously created Communication User must be assigned to this system for the following steps. Furthermore, no additional system-level settings (regarding outbound communication) are necessary, as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses inbound services.

If no related user exists, you can create a new one as follows: Navigate to the S/4HANA Public Cloud app â€œCommunication Systemsâ€.

Select Communication Systems

Select â€œNewâ€.

Select "New"

Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant and proceed with the set up. 

Creating new Communication System

Select Inbound Only as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses Inbound Communication.

Select Inbound Only

Assign the previously created Communication User.

Assign Communication User

3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement

The final step in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components  (Communication User and Communication System) within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0395 â€“ Asset Management Master Data Integration). 

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated Plant Maintenance master data (e. g. Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication. 

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the â€œCommunication Arrangementsâ€ app. 

Select Communication Arrangements

Then click on â€œNewâ€ to create a new Communication Arrangement. 

Select "New"

Select Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

Choose SAP_COM_0395 as the Communication Scenario.

Choose Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

After the creation of the Communication Arrangement the before created Communication System will be attached. Note that the corresponding Communication User will be determined automatically.

Communication System and User

The Inbound Service of the Communication Arrangement provides us then the Service URL, that will be used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.  

Required Inbound Services

3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration

In this integration scenario we used the SAP Integration Suite as the middleware layer to enable secure and reliable data exchange between the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Therefore, the SAP Integration Suite is responsible for retrieving Plant Maintenance master data (such as Functional Locations and Equipment) from the On-Premise system and delivering it to the Public Cloud using event-driven integration flows.

Since there is no pre-delivered integration package available for this scenario, we created two custom iFlows to handle the replication of Functional Location and Equipment data. Both iFlows follow a similar structure in terms of processing logic; however, they differ in the endpoints used for communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the On-Premise system respectively.

Custom Integration Package for this Scenario

3.3.1 Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers

The first step in this implementation is to create an Event Queue in SAP Event Mesh using the Message Client. This queue serves as the trigger point for event-driven integration. When a change occurs in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system (such as an update to Functional Locations or Equipment), an event is published to the queue.

The iFlow will be later subscribed to the Event Queue and use the event as a trigger to start processing. Once triggered, the iFlow calls the related API in the On-Premise system to retrieve the full master data for the affected object. This design ensures that updates are replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud in near real-time, keeping both systems synchronized.

Note: The SAP Event Mesh â€“ Message client is typically provisioned by the BASIS administrator. If you have no existing Message Client, please refer to your BASIS team.

Once the message client was set up, navigate to it inside the SAP Integration Suite > Configure > Event Mesh.

Navigate to Message Client in SAP Integration Suite

Since our EHS scenario relates to Functional Locations and Equipment, we have created two separate event queues here. Therefore, select Create.

Select "Create"

Enter a name for the new Event Queue(e. g. opn.equipment). You can keep the remaining fields as default.

Queue Settings for opn.equipment

Then navigate to Subscriptions and select Create.

Select "Create"

Two Topic Subscriptions were required within the Event Queue Details for the Equipment:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Created/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/de/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Changed/v1

Note: Regarding the Subscription, the message-client-prefix will be typically provisioned by your BASIS team. The remaining part of the respective topic names of the Equipment event is SAP standard and can be viewed in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Equipment Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Repeat this step also for the Functional Location. Therefore again, enter a name for the new event queue (e. g. opn.FuncLoc). The following subscriptions are needed for this event queue:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Changed/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Created/v1

The Functional Location events for the Functional Locations can be found in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Functional Location Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the created integration flows (iFlows) must authenticate against three endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud â€“ to push the synchronized data to the cloud system.
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise â€“ to retrieve Functional Location and Equipment data
  • SAP Event Mesh â€“ to consume events via AMQP protocol and trigger the integration process.

Note: To ensure secure authentication for each endpoint used by the iFlow, a dedicated Security Material object was created for every connection. In our demo environment, Basic Authentication was sufficient; however, for productive landscapes, certificate-based authentication is required to meet security standards and comply with enterprise policies.

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used in this scenario. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Security Material

The Security Material that was used for communication with the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, was created in a similar way using Basic Authentication, based on the credentials of the On-Premise user. Note that the On-Premise user will be provided by your SAP BASIS team.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Security Material

For the Event Mesh Security Material that enables communication with SAP Event Mesh, OAuth 2.0 was used for authentication. Therefore, enter the Token Service URL, Client ID and Client Secret, which are provided by the service key of your SAP Event Mesh Instance in SAP BTP Cockpit.

SAP Integration Suite - Event Mesh Security Material

3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment

Regarding the iFlows we will setup the Equipment Integration iFlow first. Therefore, create the iFlow with a corresponding name, set SAP S/4HANA as Sender and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as Receiver.

Sender and Receiver Setup for Equipment iFlow

The integration flow starts with an AMQP connection to SAP Event Mesh. This connection allows the iFlow to subscribe to event queues and consume messages whenever Functional Location or Equipment changes occur in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. The AMQP protocol ensures reliable, event-driven communication between the systems and acts as the trigger for the subsequent OData calls.

Therefore, connect the Receiver with the Start Message using the Adapter Type AMQP with Websocket as Transport Protocol.

First iFlow Step - AMQP Adapter Setup

The General tab inside the Adapter can stay as default. In the Connection tab you need to add a Host, Port and Path of the Event Mesh Service Key. You will find this Service Key in the Event Mesh Instance of your SAP BTP Cockpit. For Authentication use OAuth 2.0 and add the associated Security Material for Event Mesh (created in the previous step) as Credential Name.

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

In the Processing tab, add the event queue name for the equipment.

Assign Event Queue opn.equipment to AMQP Adapter

The incoming event message from SAP Event Mesh is delivered in JSON format. Since subsequent processing steps and OData calls require XML, the JSON to XML Converter transforms the payload accordingly. In this scenario, namespace mapping is disabled because the JSON structure does not include namespaces that need to be preserved in the XML output. The remaining parts of the Converter can stay as default.

JSON to XML Converter

After the conversion to XML, we added a Content Modifier. This Content Modifier is used to extract specific values from the XML structure and store them as Message Header and Exchange Properties.

Content Modifier Setup - General

In the Message Header tab, the Content Modifier reads values from the XML payload using XPath and sets them as message headers. In our example, we set the SAP_ApplicationID header with the Functional Location value found at /root/data/Equipment in the XML.

Content Modifier Setup - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab, the Content Modifier creates two properties by extracting values from the XML payload using XPath: p_eventType from /root/type and p_equipmentno from /root/data/Equipment. These properties are later used to dynamically build the OData request URL for the GET call to the on-premise system.

Content Modifier Setup - Exchange Property

Next, we set a Request Reply with the name Get Equipment Data. This enables us to get the data via OData Adapter from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Connection tab of the OData adapter, we define how the integration flow connects to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. In our example, the address consists of the virtual host and port provided by the SAP Cloud Connector, followed by the OData service path /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_EQUIPMENT/, which is the standard endpoint for the Equipment API in SAP Gateway. The proxy type is set to â€œOn-Premiseâ€, and the Location ID refers to the configured Cloud Connector destination (can be found in the Master Instance for your Cloud Connector in the SAP BTP Cockpit > Logged in into your Subaccount > Connectivity > Cloud Connectors). Regarding the authentication, was used with the on-premise related Security Material.

Note: We leveraged an existing SAP Cloud Connector configuration to securely connect the SAP Integration Suite to the on-premise system without exposing the real backend host.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Connection

Note that the API_EQUIPMENT is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_EQUIPMENT OData Service.  

In the Processing tab, we configured a GET operation to the Resource Path Equipment. Therefore, click Select.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose Connection Source Remote. The fields will be automatically filled with the provided data in the Connection tab. Then click on Step 2. If the connection is configured correctly, we will configure the operation and entities here.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Then select the operation â€œGETâ€, the Select Entity â€œEquipmentâ€, the Sub Levels 1 and choose â€œSelect All Fieldsâ€.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

To retrieve only the changes for the specific Equipment Number, apply a filter on the property ${property.p_equipmentno} that was set in the Content Modifier earlier. Filter for the ValidityEndDate as shown below.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 3

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 4

After retrieving the equipment data from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we ensured with a message mapping step that the structure and fields of the incoming data match with the expected values for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For our related message mapping we used a predefined mapping resource (/MM.mmap) created in the iFlow to transform the received data to the expected structure.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

After completing the mapping as required for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Equipment Inbound Service, we set a new Request Reply with an OData V2 adapter to the receiver endpoint of the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

In the Connection tab add the inbound service URL for the Equipment provided by the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

Choose Proxy Type Internet and add your Security Material that was created for communication with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Basic Authentication.

As we want to send the structure which the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system expects, we need to create new processing details for this OData Adapter. Therefore, choose the Processing tab and navigate to Select.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose again the Connection Source Remote. The required details to connect with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system will be shown here again automatically after the previous details in the Connection tab have been configured. Then navigate to Step 2.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Now choose the Operation Post, Entity Equipment, Sub Levels 1 and Select All Fields. For the Post operation no filters are required.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

Note: The iFlow also shows an Exception Subprocess. You can perform this after the implementation of the iFlow is finished. In our scenario we let the Exception Subprocess empty.

Exception Subprocess

3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup â€“ Functional Locations

The iFlow for the Functional Locations was similar in architecture, with small changes.

Created iFlow for Functional Location

For the AMQP Adapter at beginning of the iFlow, the event queue for Functional Location was used.

Used Event Queue in iFlow Funcional Location

According to Content Modifier > Message Header, the used Source Value was /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab of the Content Modifier, we changed the second line entry to the Name p_functionallocation and its Source Value to /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Exchange Property

According to the Get Functional Location Data that will perform a GET operation to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we used the OData Service for â€œAPI_FUNCTIONALLOCATIONâ€ with the root address /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION/. Note again that the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION OData Service. 

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Processing tab navigate to Select and go to Step 2 (As the fields required for the system connection will be filled automatically).

Choose the Operation and Select Entity as shown below with Sub Level 1 and Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

Regarding the query, we were only filtering for FunctionalLocationLabelName equals ${property.p_functionallocation}.

The Message Mapping now needs to be performed for the Functional Location. Therefore, we used again the Resource /MM.mmap but now with a new mapping.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

For the last OData Adapter sending the transformed Functional Location data from the SAP Integration Suite to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Inbound Service URL for the Functional Location was used in the Address Field of the Connection Details.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System - Connection

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

According to the Processing details, the connection to the system will be again filled automatically. Then Navigate to Step 2 and choose the Select Entity as well as the Operation as shown below. Choose again Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

3.4 Monitoring

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that event-driven integration for EHS Risk Management runs reliably across SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud & On-Premise) and the SAP Integration Suite. Accurate and timely event processing is essential because many risk-related processes depend on these events. Missing or delayed events can lead to incomplete risk assessments, gaps in safety measures, and potential compliance violations.

The Monitoring can be performed at all three involved systems.

3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Regarding the Outbound Events that are sent from the on-premise system to the SAP Integration Suite, you can navigate to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Monitoring > Monitor Event Queues.

If any failures for the Outbound Events occur, they can be analyzed here.

Event Monitor in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, monitoring focuses on API communication rather than event queues. The primary tool that can be used here is the â€œOData Error Logâ€ app, which provides detailed error messages for failed OData requests. This is essential for troubleshooting issues when SAP Integration Suite sends data to the Public Cloud system.

OData Error Log in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

3.4.3 SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows. As already described already in the part 2 you can therefore navigate within the SAP Integration Suite to Monitor > Overview > Manage Integration Content. Here you can select your respective iFlow (e.g. â€œFunctional Location Integration in between SAP S4HANA and SAP S4HANA Cloudâ€) and select Monitor Message Processing.

Manage Integration Content for Functional Location iFlow

This view provides a clear overview of the processing status for each message, indicating whether it was completed successfully or if any errors occurred during execution.

Monitor Message Processing

By selecting Message Status Overview on the upper right corner,  statistics will be shown across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues. 

Message Status Overview

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing this integration scenario via the scope item 4HH for Plant Maintenance data (such as Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provided several valuable insights that are highly relevant for similar integration projects.

1. Event-Driven Integration Ensures Real-Time Accuracy: Using SAP Event Mesh with AMQP is critical for keeping Functional Location and Equipment data synchronized. Batch jobs cannot guarantee timely updates for EHS processes like Risk Management.

2. Validate OData Services Early: Missing activation of API_EQUIPMENT or API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION in the on-premise system is a common root cause for iFlow failures. Always check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE before starting.

3. Topic Naming in Event Mesh Requires Precision: Incorrect prefixes or typos in topic subscriptions will block event processing entirely. Always cross-check against SAP Business Accelerator Hub references.

4. Message Mapping Is Compliance-Critical: Ensure that Equipment and Functional Location data is transformed correctly for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Missing mandatory fields can lead to incomplete risk assessments and reporting gaps.

5. Monitoring Is Essential for Operational Reliability: Event-driven integration depends on timely message processing. Use monitoring tools in all three systems (SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP Integration Suite, and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud) to detect and resolve issues early.

6. Plan Authentication Strategy Upfront: Basic Authentication works for demos, but production environments require certificate-based authentication. Delaying this switch can cause project delays and security risks.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal

  • @asutoshmaharana2326 
  • @kanwal_singh
  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

entry.title: How to Use Long Texts in Service Transactions
entry.content:
Introduction

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, "long texts" refer to extended textual information that can be included in various documents or transactions within the SAP system, such as sales orders, invoices, and service contracts. These texts are used to provide detailed descriptions, instructions, terms, and conditions that go beyond the standard fields available in the documents or transactions.

In this blog, we will explain the behaviors relevant to long texts in your system when you use the Service area in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Additionally, you will read about a special business case that demonstrates how you can manipulate the long texts that SAP has pre-delivered for you.

Facts About Long Texts in Service Transactions

Here are some key facts about using long texts in service transactions:

  1. In the Service area, long texts are referred to as â€œNotes,â€ a term inherited from the SAP Customer Relationship Management world, especially visible in the user interfaces of Service apps. 
  2. You can use SAP pre-delivered text types via the value help in respective Service apps. Currently, you can't custom text types for individual service transactions. 
  3. SAP delivers text types that may vary between service transactions and between header and item levels. For instance, you may find a text type available in service contracts but not in service orders, or you might be able to choose a text type in the service contract header but not at the item level. You can read about all the texts for service contracts in the SAP Help Portal documentation: Texts for Service Contracts. 
  4. We believe that the existing text types can accommodate most of your business requirements. If you have special business needs, you can still use the existing text types to provide the necessary information for your service transactions. 
  5. If you want the system to carry a long text/note from a service contract to a service order, you need to understand that there must be a copying control logic working in the backend. SAP has designed this copying control logic to determine how the transfer triggers, and you cannot customize this process. For example, if you wish to transfer some data from a service contract to a service order, the copying control works when you assign service contracts to a service order item. This process is known as â€œservice contract determination.â€ You can find a good example of this in the blog Copying of Notes in Service Contract Items to Service Order Items.

In this blog, you will read about an example that showcases facts No. 4 and No. 5 mentioned above. 

Business Scenario

In this scenario, you work for an Italian company, and you need to note down the CIG codes in service contracts and in the corresponding service orders due to compliance requirements in Italy. 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the following facts apply: 

  1. In service contracts, the CIG text type is available only at the header level because CIG, issued by the government for contractors, typically corresponds to one contractor per service contract. The same reasoning applies to CUP.

     

  2. In service orders, the CIG text type is not available at either the header or item level.
  3. Even if the CIG text type were available in service orders, the system cannot copy CIG from the service contract header to the service order item due to the logic of service contract determination, which only functions at the item level.

Solution

To address your business requirement, we suggest the following solution: use a text type that exists in both service contract items and service order items, specifically SC01 Service Implementation Instruction.  

Perform the following tasks so that you can test the solution in your own system. 

  1. Open the Manage Service Contracts app. Create a service contract that contains a service contract item. Navigate to the Notes section of the item details page, add a new note using the text type Service Implementation Instruction with the CIG information, and then release the item. 
  2. Go to the Manage Service Orders app. Create a service order with the same sold-to party that you have specified in the service contract. Ensure that the â€œRequested Start Date - End Dateâ€ of the service order falls within the validity period (start date â€“ end date) of the service contract. 
  3. Upon creating the service order, the system prompts you to select a service contract item. Directly search for the service contract and the item you just created. 
  4. After the assignment, go to the details page of the service order item. In the Notes section, you will find that the CIG code is already there. 

Conclusion

This blog presents a clear and efficient method for handling CIG codes in the long texts in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Service. By utilizing the SC01 Service Implementation Instruction text type, you can successfully manage data transfer between service contract items and service order items. This approach bypasses limitations associated with header-level text types and leverages the item-level logic intrinsic to service contract determination. By following the outlined steps, you can ensure accurate and seamless data integration across contracts and orders, enhancing overall system functionality and reliability.  

Additional Information

You can learn more about Service Contract Determination in SAP Help Portal:  Service Contract Determination.

entry.title: Whatâ€™s New in SAP Field Service Management 2511
entry.content:
Welcome to SAP Field Service Management 2511 â€“ our final release in a year filled with exciting innovations for field service organizations. As always, we have summarized the key highlights and included demo videos for you to explore.

SAP Field Service Management 2511 continues our investment in AI-driven scheduling, mobile productivity, and streamlined workforce coordination. New capabilities in crew planning, the service map, the dispatching board, and the mobile app help organizations plan smarter, execute faster, and reduce administrative effort across the field service lifecycle.

For the complete list of all features in the 2511 release, click here.

Key Highlights in SAP Field Service Management 2511

  • Crew Management enhancements â€“ partial-day crew assignments and clearer visibility into where technicians are staffed throughout the day.
  • Service Map improvements â€“ lasso selection for geo-based bulk assignment and skills validation when scheduling directly from the map.
  • AI scheduling transparency and control â€“ exclude released activities during rearrange runs, use Best Matching Technician reports to understand ranking and technician selection, and leverage configurable service call summaries to quickly review all work performed.
  • AI-powered Smartform translation on mobile â€“ translate Smartforms into other languages in seconds while preserving structure, integrity, and context.
  • Faster mobile wrap-up with group checkout â€“ check out activities from multiple service calls in one step, with options for consolidated or separate reports.

AI-Driven Scheduling and Dispatching

Check out the highlights in the demo video below:

 

Exclude released activities during rearrange

Dispatchers must optimize routes and reduce travel time â€“ but once a job is released to a technician, it often should not be moved. In 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces the ability to exclude released activities from schedule rearrange runs.

In practice, a dispatcher can select a technicianâ€™s schedule, run a rearrange based on the selected policy, and view proposed changes and sequences before applying them â€“ all while released jobs remain locked in place. This reduces the risk of disrupting work already communicated to the technician and provides a more controlled optimization experience, especially in high-volume operations. More info here. 

 

 

Service call summaries

From the service call, dispatchers and back-office staff can now execute an AI-generated service call summary to obtain an overview of all activities performed on a single service call. Furthermore, such summaries can easily be configured to represent only the most relevant information.

By consolidating key information into a single view, service call summaries reduce the time spent piecing together what happened on a job, and help dispatchers or back-office staff review, document, close, and move on to the next case more efficiently. More info here. 

 

Conditional color formatting in the activity list

To improve contextual awareness, dispatchers can now use conditional color formatting in the activity list. Instead of scanning long lists of jobs, planners can define simple conditions that change how activities appear.

For example, based on configuration, all jobs for a key customer such as Alpha Corporation might appear in blue, while IoT generated activities show in red. These visual cues help dispatchers quickly distinguish high-priority, automated, or specialized work without opening each activity. The result is faster triage, fewer misses, and a more intuitive way to work through large backlogs. More info here. 

 

Best Matching Technician scheduling reports

Best Matching Technician (BMT) helps dispatchers quickly identify the right resource based on skills, availability, and other criteria. With 2511, SAP Field Service Management adds scheduling reports for BMT to increase transparency into why certain technicians are selected â€“ and why others are excluded.

When running a BMT search, dispatchers can now see a report that explains the ranking of technicians, including which criteria contributed positively and where requirements were not met. Drilling into the report reveals the individual scoring per technician, making it easier to understand how the autoscheduler behaves in BMT scenarios. This added transparency builds trust in AI-assisted decisions and helps planners fine-tune their data and rules over time. More info here. 

 

Recurring reservations for planned time blocks

Managing training, safety sessions, or any other repeated commitments can become a manual burden when each time block must be created individually. In 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces recurring reservations for person reservations.

Dispatchers can now define recurring patterns â€“ for example, schedule a technician for safety training over the next two weeks, every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 8:00 to 11:00. The recurring reservation can be managed as a series or on a single-day basis, with options to adjust dates, times, weekdays, and frequency. This simplifies repetitive reservation planning and makes calendars more accurate for both dispatchers and technicians. More info here. 

 

Mobile Field Service

Check out the highlights in the demo video below:

 

AI-powered Smartform translation

Smartforms are critical for capturing structured data in the field, but localizing them into multiple languages has traditionally required multiple manual steps. With 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces AI-powered Smartform translation.

Using AI, customers can translate Smartforms into multiple languages in just a few steps. For example, an existing English Smartform can be translated into Spanish, resulting in a fully functional form for Spanish-speaking technicians. Translations preserve the formâ€™s structure, integrity, and context, enabling field service organizations operating in multiple languages to deploy localized forms in seconds, rather than hours or days.

On mobile, technicians see the translated form in their native language, with all critical fields intact. This improves data quality, adoption, and user experience for global workforces. More info here. 

 

Group checkout across multiple service calls

Technicians frequently complete work for several service calls in a single route. Previously, group checkout reporting was limited to activities within one service call at a time. With 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces group checkout across multiple service calls.

Technicians can now select activities from different service calls and perform a single checkout step, streamlining the wrap-up process at the end of a shift or route. They can choose whether to generate one consolidated report for all selected activities, or separate reports per service call.

This reduces administrative overhead, shortens the gap between execution and documentation, and helps ensure reporting remains compliant with internal and customer requirements. More info here. 

 

Service Map, Crews, and Crowd Service

Check out the highlights in the demo video below:

 

Lasso selection on the service map

The service map is central to location-aware dispatching. In 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces lasso selection to help dispatchers assign groups of activities using geographic context.

On the map, dispatchers can draw a lasso around all jobs in a particular area, then drag the selected activities onto a technicianâ€™s schedule. The activities are automatically placed according to the organizationâ€™s predefined scheduling policy (for example, based on SLA). This approach combines visual, map-based planning with automated scheduling logic â€“ accelerating dispatcher workflows by reducing manual drag-and-drop, respecting geography, and assigning work in bulk. More info here. 

 

Skills validation when scheduling from the service map

Scheduling directly from the map becomes more intelligent with skills validation. When a dispatcher drags an activity from the service map onto a technicianâ€™s schedule, the system now checks for any skill conflicts.

If a technician lacks the required certification, skill, or qualification for the job, a notification appears, allowing the dispatcher to adjust the assignment before confirming. This ensures that requirements such as geography and skills are both considered in the scheduling process, helping organizations maintain safety and compliance while still working visually from the map. More info here.

 

Partial-day crew assignments

Crew Management in 2511 introduces support for partial-day crew assignments, enabling more precise allocation of technicians across multiple crews throughout the day.

Dispatchers can assign a technician to one crew in the morning and another crew in the afternoon. Time-specific assignments can be managed as a series or as individual days, with clear visibility into each technicianâ€™s crew allocation. For example, a technician may be staffed on Crew X from 8:00 to 12:00, then allocated to a Crew Y from 12:00 to 18:00.

These partial-day assignments give planners greater flexibility to maximize resource utilization for dynamic field service operations, while the dispatching board clearly reflects dynamic crew assignments throughout the day. More info here.

 

 

Crowd Service list view

For organizations working with external contractors, Crowd Service helps coordinate third-party resources. In 2511, a new list view provides a more efficient way to manage crowd assignments and activity distribution.

Dispatchers can review contractor jobs and take bulk action on groups of activities from a single list. This enhancement supports high-volume contractor operations where quick adjustments and bulk updates are essential. More info here.

 

Administration

Shell notifications with direct links

Shell notifications now support hyperlinks, making it easier to move from insight to action. For example, when a dispatcher is notified about events such as a closed activity, they can open the notification and jump directly to the relevant object with a single click.

This reduces navigation time, helps dispatchers stay focused in high-volume environments, and ensures that important events can be followed up on immediately, while linking to critical information. More info here. 

 

Enhanced admin control for client assignment

In 2511, admins can control which FSM clients each user may access â€“ for example iOS, Android, or shell only. At user level, you define the allowed platforms and block everything else, helping ensure technicians connect only from approved, managed devices and aligning FSM access with corporate mobility policies. More info here. 

 

Extensions

New commercial extension â€œSkill Managerâ€

A new third-party extension, Skill Manager from partner Elephantis, is now available in the SAP Field Service Management Extension Directory. Skill Manager helps field service teams manage technician skills in a grid-style view, with visual indicators for valid, expiring or expired skills, along with advanced filtering options. This makes it easier to keep certifications current and ensure the right technicians are assigned to the right work. More info here. 

 

Final Thoughts

SAP Field Service Management 2511 sharpens how planners, dispatchers, and technicians work together â€“ with clearer schedules, smarter maps, and faster mobile workflows.

Released-activity protection in rearrange simulations, BMT reports, recurring reservations, and service call summaries give dispatchers more control and transparency. Technicians benefit from AI-translated Smartforms, recurring reservations on mobile, and group checkout across service calls.

With lasso selection, skills validation on the map, and partial-day crew assignments, planners and dispatchers can align the right resources to the right work more efficiently â€“ whether they are internal teams or contractors.

We look forward to your feedback through Influence, the SAP Community, and upcoming webinars.

In Public Cloud, there is no single released CDS view that reliably provides the full breakdown of totals across all credit exposure categories 100/200/300/400/500 in the same way the standard Fiori apps do.

What you observed with I_CreditExposureItem is expected by design:

  • I_CreditExposureItem reads credit exposure items from backend table UKM_ITEM

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003517767

2. If you truly need a category-level breakdown (100/200/300/400/500)
There isnâ€™t a released CDS that gives you that full breakdown out of the box. Practically you have these options:

  • Use I_CreditExposureItem for the categories it actually covers (typically SD/LE-related, like 100/400/500) and accept itâ€™s not complete

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/93e5af96e585443b9481349e9fec8545.html

  • Raise an SAP request (influence / support) to release an API/CDS artifact that exposes the category totals in a stable way since I_CreditExposureItem is explicitly missing 200 by design

Best Regards,

entry.title: Understanding Regex in JavaScript - A Beginner-Friendly Guide
entry.content:
Quick Introduction:

When working with JavaScript, we will often find ourselves needing to search, validate or modify text. Thatâ€™s where Regex comes in.

In this blog, we will break down what regex is, why itâ€™s useful, and how to start using it with simple examples.

 

What is Regex?

Regex is a powerful & smart search tool that lets you find patterns in text almost like giving your code a mini detective to look for clues inside a string.

Regex (short for Regular Expression) is a special pattern used to search, match and replace text.

In other words, regex is a pattern-matching language used in many programming languages, including JavaScript to:

  • Search for text
  • Match specific patterns
  • Replace parts of a string

For example, we might need to check if a sentence contains a word, extract all numbers from a paragraph or validate an email address. Regex makes these tasks fast, efficient and reliable.

 

Why do use Regex in JavaScript?

Because normal search is limited. With regex, we can do so much. Regex lets you write dynamic, flexible patterns to handle more advanced text operations. Hereâ€™s what you can do with it:

  1. Validate patterns

    Modify text based on matching patterns.
    Example: Remove extra spaces or replace characters.

  2. Extraction Text

    Check if a string follows a specific format.
    Example: Is this a valid email address?

  3. Replace text

    Pull out numbers, words or custom text patterns.
    Example: Find all digits in a message.

 

Simple and Practical Examples

Letâ€™s look at how we can use regex in JavaScript with just a few lines of code.

  • Check if a word exists
const sText = "I love JavaScript";

const bResult = /JavaScript/.test(text);

console.log(bResult); // true
  • Find all numbers in a string
const sText = "My score is 95 out of 100.";

const sNumbers = sText.match(/\d+/g);

console.log(sNumbers); // ["95", "100"]
  • Replace spaces with dashes
const sResult = "hello world js".replace(/\s/g, "-");

console.log(sResult); // "hello-world-js"

 

How regex patterns are structured & how it works

Regex patterns in JavaScript are written between forward slashes:

/pattern/

Here are some common symbols:

Symbol

Meaning

\d

digit (0â€“9)

\s

whitespace (space, tab, etc.)

\w

word character (letters, numbers, _)

+

one or more

*

zero or more

Based on our requirement, we can combine these symbols to create almost any pattern we need.

In simple words, Regex is a smart text-searching tool in JavaScript. It helps us work with text faster, cleaner, and more efficiently, especially when dealing with patterns. Whether you're searching, matching or validating text, regex makes the process powerful, flexible and easy.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! I hope this helps you. If you found this helpful, please feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

Stay tuned for more Git-related commands in future blogs. Happy coding!

entry.title: Intercompany Cost allocation reconciliation â€“ Review Booklet
entry.content:
Area of Application - Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings (4AN)

Managing intercompany cost allocations during period-end closing can be complex and time-consuming. The new SAP Fiori app Intercompany Cost Allocation Reconciliation â€“ Review Booklet addresses these challenges by providing transparency across the entire document flow, from Management Accounting postings to intercompany billing and financial postings. It helps to ensure completeness and audit readiness.

Why This Matters

Cross-company cost accounting documents often originate from processes such as:

  • Time Recording for EPPM
  • Direct Activity Allocations
  • Service Confirmations
  • Concur Travel & Expense

These postings typically exclude tax and may not comply with global transfer pricing regulations. Legal invoices that include tax are required for compliance. SAPâ€™s Resource-Related Intercompany Billing (RRICB) functionality (scope item 4AN - Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings) enables creation of intercompany invoices for these Management Accounting postings. Invoice creation is followed by the transfer to General Ledger (and Accounts Receivable), then the automatic mirroring of Accounts Payable documents in the receiving company. For additional details, please refer to the blog by @stefan_walz on Intercompany Cost Allocations in S/4HANA Cloud.

However, ensuring completeness by identifying services and expenses that are relevant for intercompany billing and are already billed, partially billed, or not yet billed, and then providing audit-relevant transparency during closing has been a critical challenge - until now.

Introducing the Intercompany Cost Allocation Reconciliation â€“ Review Booklet

This review booklet delivers:

  • End-to-end document flow reporting on intercompany cost allocations
    Trace postings from Management Accounting (CO) to Billing Documents and Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable entries.
  • Status visibility
    Identify services and expenses that are billed, partially billed, or unbilled.
  • Audit-ready transparency
    Simplify reconciliation and reduce manual effort.

Scope

The review booklet covers intercompany transactions relevant for intercompany billing, including:

  • Timesheet postings (including contingent workers) and cancellations
  • Activity allocations (including margin postings) and cancellations
  • Reassigning/reposting costs and revenues (only cost reposting is considered for intercompany billing)
  • Settlement postings
  • Concur T&E
  • Universal Allocations and cancellations
  • Service Order Confirmations and cancellations

For the most current overview, see Intercompany Postings.

Out of scope:
Transactions posted via other processes (such as Advanced Intercompany Sales, General Journal Entries).

Prerequisites

The review booklet is delivered via feature toggle and is not automatically available in your system. To use it:

  • Activate scope item 4AN â€“ Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings.
  • Configure New Resource Related Intercompany Billing. For details, see
    Generate Intercompany Billing Request (New Solution).
  • Activate feature Intercompany Cost Allocation Reconciliation (CO_ICO_DOCFLOW) in the configuration activity Activate Features.

How to Use the App

The app is available in the Cost Accountant â€“ Overhead business role.
Steps:

Open the Intercompany Cost Allocation Reconciliation â€“ Review Booklet app.


Enter mandatory filters: Sender and Receiver Company Codes, Fiscal Year (CO), and Posting Period (CO).

Click Go to view documents that are classified as Billed or Unbilled.

The report uses clear labeling to identify information. Labels include the:

  • (CO) suffix for Management Accounting postings
  • (FI) suffix for General Ledger postings
  • Sender prefix for the invoice issuing/supplying company code
  • Receiver prefix for the invoice receiving/ordering company code

Constraints

The app is under active development. It was first delivered with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and is enhanced with 2602. We welcome and appreciate all feedback. Note there are currently some constraints in using the app:

  • Data will not display for the Receiver Journal Entry (FI) dimension unless you activate the feature Payables Posting for Classic Intercompany Invoice via bgPF (S4HC_SDBIL_ICO_IDOC_REMOVAL) in the Activate Features configuration activity. 
  • If you activate the use of general journal entries in the configuration step Activate Usage of General Journal Entries (107009) for New Resource Related Intercompany Billing, those records are not included in the document flows.
  • You must activate the new intercompany billing solution by performing the configuration for New Resource Related Intercompany Billing. 
  • Intercompany billing completed with the old solution appears as not billed in the document flow. Re-billed transactions using the new solution will display correctly.

Next Steps

Activate the feature, explore the app, and experience streamlined intercompany cost allocation reconciliation. Share your feedback to help shape future improvements.

Good day @william_p 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Universal Journal Entry, Debit/Credit Shift Between FSV Nodes, Defining the Debit/Credit Shift

The Debit/Credit Shift between FSV Nodes is only for reporting-time presentation rule, which is used only during financial statement rendering. The status is not stored in ACDOCA, it is also not exposed through any CDS view or API and it also does not provide any flag that indicates whether an account was posted as an asset or liability after shift. That means you cannot retrieve the shift configuration in the FSV using a program.

You can access data like G/L account classification such as Asset, Liability, Equity, Expense through CDS views like I_GLAccountInChartOfAccounts. You can then join this with journal entries through A_JournalEntryItemAPI01 or I_JournalEntryItem. However, the shifted representation used in FSV cannot be extracted.

A COMPLETE_DATA_BACKUP from SAP HANA 1.0 is system-specific and cannot be restored to another server unless the target system matches the original system ID, topology, and configuration. Please refer to the SAP HANA Administration Guide for supported recovery scenarios.
